children.subject:
It's likely they will give us more information in the next few days (or even next day, not sure). You should probably continue doing what your doing, it's not the best idea to worry about what grad school people will think about, please don't stress about it at the moment. If you are in a tough life situation, you should prioritize that, not CS 170. Please take care of your health and family members at this time, it's more important than your grade--that situation will resolve itself when we have more word from the school. Sorry about the nature of my answer, but please try not to worry about 170 if you have other personal matters to handle as they are probably more important!

It's a strange situation for the entire world right now, so to answer your grad. school question, they will not have amnesia about the current situation, they will probably know why it says PNP (if that happens). Stay safe and healthy and try not to add unnecessary stress!
I hardly think a grad school would forget what happened in Spring 2020 and negatively penalize applicants for that. I'd venture to say most will be understanding if you do choose to P/NP courses.
I heard that instructors assign letter grade without knowing who chose PNP. At this moment any speculation about curve is without much substantial evidence.

https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/faculty-staff/academic-personnel/grading-guidelines-undergrad

"The GPA for a course does not include grades for students who elect a Passed/Not Passed (P/NP) grading option."

Ya, in my CS class they have a progress checker, and when asked, the head TA said pass no pass students don’t count in calculations....

also, Anonymous Beaker, I think Grad schools will still find it suspect that we opted for a P/NP if a letter grade was offered—it would just mean our performance was bad to them. And justifying your own personal circumstances yourself is really difficult (trust me Ik the system can be pretty harsh)

This idea that "grad. schools" will not be forgiving about this situation seems very pessimistic and not a healthy way to view the current situation. The "grad. schools" are not this evil group of people hiding in closets who come out only to criticize students during application season. They are your professors! They are your department staff, past professors/admin/other people who are themselves having a hard time handling the situation personally and professionally, have been reading our desperate Piazza complaints about situations like this, and have been really involved in the discussions which determine the exact grading policy their school will take in this situation. They may not be Berkeley people, but they will have gone through all of this all the same. I have gone to many graduate school talks given by professors, talked to professors in OH, all of whom have been on admissions committees, and who will talk about how personal and difficult the review process actually is. Applications to grad school aren't like undergrad where a school will have 100,000 applications, sometimes with no letters of rec. and no prior experiences. Your grad school application will have SO many more dimensions to it and far more components to it. Their first question will not be "what grade did this student get in CS__ in spring 2020?" It will be "With whom did they do that research project with? What did that faculty member/recommender have to save about the student, and what did the student have to say about their project and future interests? Was the project meaningful, and did they work well with their faculty? Do we see the student succeeding here, do we have faculty who have similar interests and who are willing and able to advise them? ... many questions later ... What grade did they get in CS__" (if they even ask that question!). Berkeley didn't cancel this semester, so there still aren't any good reasons not to just focus on our own performance in classes, how to gain as much meaningful learning even with zoom and other personal matters to think about.
I'm not even planning on going to grad school but if the curve really doesn't take into consideration P/NP students' performances then I'd be really sad as that will make it so much harder to do well

Why would it make it harder to do well? We may just have different priorities, but if I wasn't applying to grad. school or if I had not other reason that my grades would need to be optimal, then why do my grades matter? Doing well then is entirely dependent on how much I get from the course, theoretically/practically/for enjoyment, and what does this have to do with other students? I hate to be that guy who just says "don't compare yourself to your peers," but really, there is no reason that other student's decision about PNP has any effect on how much you learn from the course. If doing well for you is synonymous with getting a good grade, then sure--it may be harder to do well (and even here you are assuming that there are only few perfectionist students who PNP just out of fear of getting a B+ rather than an A-). If you are someone who doesn't equate doing well and being successful with getting a good grade, then you don't need to be thinking too much about what other's are doing. I know someone who graduated with 2.9 overall gpa and who is doing very well at Google, and others who went to grad. school and are struggling. Anyways, it's hopefully something to ease peoples’ minds about all of this--more optimism will help us all in a time like this!

It is SOOOOOO sad that they didn't take this into account when making their decision. They actually are kind of hurting us now, because curves will be worse, and we have to opt into letter grades for grad schools. They should have either done nothing or gone all P/NP...

history.content:
P/NP that stuff homie 

People are literally dying, profs are gonna understand 1 semester of P/NP

Take care of yourself, P/NP - it's not gonna matter

Your letters and research matter more to begin with, people spend less than 20 seconds on the transcript

Considering all the talk about PNP and mandatory or whatnot, will it be harmful to pass no pass 170 or other CS upper divs for grad school? Will they care about these circumstances? I'm worried because I am in a tough situation relating to corona and need to know where to put my time.
history.subject: Effects of PNP CS upper divs on Grad School
